title: 108_hr3079
content: The National Commission on the Modernization of the United Nations Act of 2003 establishes a commission with duties to modernize the United Nations. The Commission established by the National Commission on the Modernization of the United Nations Act of 2003 is tasked with conducting studies, recommending reforms, and enumerating methods for implementation. This includes studying the extent of modernization within the current UN Charter without requiring substantive changes, and making recommendations for modernization that may necessitate modifications to the Charter. The Commission established by the National Commission on the Modernization of the United Nations Act of 2003 is studying the extent of modernization within the current UN Charter and making recommendations for potential modifications to implement modernization. This includes studying member state principles and whether states that go against the Charter should be allowed membership. The Commission is studying the feasibility of mandating regular reviews by the United Nations to determine if member states adhere to Charter principles and what actions should be taken against states that violate the Charter. The Commission is studying the requirement for member states to sign a declaration agreeing to adhere to UN principles and review if the UN is implementing the Charter. Additionally, they are studying whether all states should have equal voting rights in the General Assembly. The Commission is studying the structure of the United Nations, including whether it should be bi-cameral, funding for auxiliary commissions, and the use of peacekeeping and humanitarian efforts. The Commission is studying the United Nations structure, including the need for a separate peacekeeping force and past successes in humanitarian efforts. They are also examining the credibility of resolutions when absolute obedience is not mandated. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. Membership details are outlined in section 4. The Commission shall consist of 9 members appointed by various officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, and others. Each member serves for the life of the Commission. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various officials and each member serves for the life of the Commission. A member appointed to the Commission cannot continue if they become a government officer or employee. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairperson is elected by members after consultation with specific leaders, and travel expenses are provided to each member. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR AND STAFF. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed for life, with vacancies filled in the same manner. The Chairperson is elected by members after consultation with specific leaders. The Commission appoints a Director paid at level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director can hire additional staff with Commission approval, following certain civil service laws for appointments and pay rates. The Commission can request personnel from Federal agencies and administrative support services from the General Services Administrator on a reimbursable basis to assist in carrying out its duties under this Act. The Commission has the power to hold meetings, obtain official data from US departments, and use the US mails. They can request support services from the General Services Administrator. They are also required to submit reports. The Commission established by the Act must submit an interim report to Congress within 6 months and a final report within 12 months. The Commission will terminate 15 days after submitting the final report. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Charter" refers to the Charter of the United Nations, "Commission" refers to the National Commission on the Modernization of the United Nations, and "member" refers to a member of the Commission.
